lettertext.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

17 May
1592.
M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.299r
May it please yo
r
good L.
Count Maurice
, it
is thought, hath already inclosed
e towne of
steen-
wicke
, and beginnes therupon to make his appro-
ches. The
Councel of Estate
goeth thither-
wardes to morowe, w
t
purpose to continue for
e
time of
at service. But
e general assemblie
of
e states of every Province doth remaine at
e
Hage: albeit for some fortnight their meeting is
differred. During w
ch
time, and untill I am
advertised of her
Hig
nes
pleasure, as touching
at
w
ch
I proposed upon
e motion of
e states, for
e
enterprise of
Britaine,
I will be alwaies with
e Councel: but to returne againe hither, when
yo
r
L. letter comes unto me, to negotiat with
e
states. Heere is a gentleman of
Juliers,
at
maketh an offer to this contrey, to be ready to serve
where they will appoint, w
t
2000 foote, to be rai-
sed in
e land of
Cleve
and Juliers, and to come
unto them upon 6 weekes warning: to be so inter-
tened from three monethes to three monethes, upon
e receat of halfe pay, till their service be required.
The
states
have concluded to accept of this offer,
and to reserve
e imploiement of
e men, till they
knowe w
at
her Ma
tie
will determine for Britaine,
or till perhaps they shall have neede, through the
Enemies attemptes, while their forces are at steen-
wicke, to defende some other place, in some part
of these Provinces. There hath not passed as
yet any perfit contract, between
e states and
e gentleman, by reason of certaine mony whiche
the partie demaundeth to be paieed before hand,
and
e states will not graunt: howbeit we are
alwaies in hope, that they will come to a good agreement.
fol.299v
The practise upon
Enchusen,
wherof I writte
in a former, is delaied by
e Enemie, but we
knowe not yet
e reason. In
e cause of
the company of
e
Marchants Adventurers
, there
hath bin heere
a
meeting of Deputies on bothe sides:
who are well agreed upon divers pointes: but
the chiefest are referred, by mutual consent, to
the ordering of
e states, who have taken fur-
ther time. In
e meane while there is a kinde
of contentment given to them all, and their
trafficke is free, as it was before.
And thus
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
May 17 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
